author: jih2nn
content:
> yes: one assumption that rollups *do not make* on L1 is that an attacker holds < 50% of the stake. And it makes sense not to make this assumption because the rollup bridge may contain more than that value. FOCIL would be fantastic to guarantee censor resistance in less than a challenge period without this assumption, but unfortunately it needs it

<@755590043632140352> I guess the stake means the staked tokens in a rollup contract? What happens when an attacker holds >50% of the stake?

author: potuz
content: In FOCIL, if the attacker holds more than 50% of the stake, you can always pretend that you didn't see the includer's ILs

author: potuz
content: and prevent the whole mechanism of working as intended

author: potuz
content: this is not something inherently bad from FOCIL, it's just the way it is with anything that is enforced off-chain

author: potuz
content: But the point is that it doesn't allow rollups to assume that there won't be censorship in any time window because they don't want to make the assumption about 50% of stake being honest, rightfully so

author: jih2nn
content: Right, so it's staked ETH in L1. Having control over >50% of total stake sounds like very strong attack, but it's always good to know which trust assumptions it's based on

author: potuz
content: Ethereum does have this security: even if an attacker has 100% of the stake, they cannot finalize an invalid block. For L2s this is not the case if their censoring mechanism requires an assumption on minimal honesty for stakers. An attacker that manages to censor for over enough time can post an invalid state transition on L2
